bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 3, 1930

div1.p: Carter is not worried about Frost's revisions to the fifth chapter of the book. She explains that Henry Rose Carter's first interest would be to get his argument clear rather than eloquent.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 3, 1930
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 3, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
4710 Keswick Road,
Roland Park, Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p: Your letter, dated August 28th., reached me yesterday.

No, I am not at all “worried” at the idea of your further revision
of Chapter V. In fact it would have been “the other way 'round.” I have al-
ways felt uneasy about that chapter, not in its fundamental argument, but, to
quote yourself, in the way “it appears on superficial reading,” and have feared
that archaeologists (other than Morley and Martinez Hernandez) might start a
lot of unnecessary argument over a matter not essential to the real epidemiologi-
cal argument for Yucatan. I am then relieved at the thought of your further
“checking up” of this chapter and not only “judge,” but know that Father's
“first interest” would be “ in getting his argument clear rather than eloquent.”
should you find it necessary to sacrifice one ofor the other. Personally, I
feel perfectly confident of your handling both sides of this matter.

Re the additional data you desire, from European records, concerning
the smallpox in Yucatan in 1520--its introduction into Cozumel by Narxaez, its
geographic spread and mortality: I have taken steps to collect, on my desk
at the Library of Congress, all of the authors you suggested (not in the Rare
Book Room) and will also, of course, follow any “side lines” that may develope.
Hope to be able to send you the result within a few days.

In the interim, in addition to the oft-quoted extract from Diaz del
Castillo, you have verbatim accounts of the “first” appearance of smallpox on
the bibliographic cards for Motolinia, Toribio de ( ) and Mendieta, Geró-
nimo de (1870); These bib. cards for iii.i. p. 22 of Father's MS. As you may
recollect, I took them over to you on myllast trip to Baltimore, in order that
you might check Father's statement as to whether it was Motolinia or Molina, who
was in agreement with Mendieta in calling the epidemic of 1531 “sarampion”
(measles). It was Motolinia. While having these cards made out, I thought it
well to preface the statements re “sarampion” with those on the smallpox of
1520. This because I remembered your saying last January that you would like
any procurable data on this subject. I think, however, that Mendieta quite
certainly copied his account from that of Motolinia, parts of it, as you
may have noticed, being almost identical.

Hope to have the maps within a few days. They are beautifully and
very carefully done. The xvith. Century map (for Ojeda, Nicuesa et al) de-
serves especial commendation, as Father (in that part of his book formerly
known as Section iii, part i, Continued) mentions places for which many con-
temporaneous maps have had to be searched and the MS itself carefully con-
sulted. This, on account of the paucity of names used by the Spaniards in
designating places in the New World and their consequent repetition at far
distant points. I expect then, that Mr. Burnham's bill will be considerably
higher, both actually and proportionately, than that sent in by Mr. Johnson,
for the partly finished maps we had to discard, and for which I am, as I told
you, ready to pay repay the I. H. D., [unclear] Mr. Weckerley's illness, and
consequent inability to do the work himself (or to check it) was the real
cause of trouble., but the matter was in my hands, “pour
faux de mieux.”
With love to “the Susans,” I remain
